content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards, chairing the Program Management Policy Council, and engaging with the private sector to identify best practices. The Deputy Director for Management oversees the implementation of governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. This includes chairing the Program Management Policy Council, establishing standards and policies, engaging with the private sector for best practices, conducting portfolio reviews, and creating a 5-year strategic plan. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar or duplicative. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. This includes establishing a 5-year strategic plan and issuing standards, policies, and guidelines within a specified timeframe. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are already covered by existing policies or regulations. The Deputy Director for Management oversees governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies, including issuing regulations to implement requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Each agency must designate a senior executive as a Program Management Improvement Officer. Sec. 1126 of the program management improvement officers and policy council requires each agency to designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer. This officer is responsible for implementing program management policies and developing strategies to enhance the role of program managers within the agency. The Program Management Improvement Officer is responsible for implementing policies and strategies to enhance the role of program managers. Training for program managers in the private sector includes relevant competencies and cost containment for large projects. The Program Management Improvement Officer is tasked with mentoring current and future program managers, improving career paths, encouraging recruitment of qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing tools for data analysis. This subsection does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10. The Program Management Improvement Officer mentors program managers, improves career paths, and provides tools for data analysis. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management and reviews high-risk programs identified by the General Accountability Office. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management on high-risk programs, workforce development, program management standards, and government transparency. The Program Management Policy Council advises on program management standards and government transparency, reviewing information published by the Office of Management and Budget. The Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management are key positions within the council. The Program Management Policy Council is chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Council meets at least twice per fiscal year, with the Chairperson determining the agenda, directing the work, and establishing subgroups as needed. Support for the Council is provided by agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers and designated federal employees or Armed Forces members. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, meets at least twice per fiscal year. Agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers provide support to the Council. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies needed for program and project managers in agencies, establish new job series or update existing ones, and create a new career path for program and project managers. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for improving Federal program and project management, including standards, guidelines, and the strategic plan established under title 31.
